channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: YouTube delete conspiracy theorist David Icke's account after he made unproven coronavirus claims
item.description: YouTube said David Icke, 68, violated its policies on sharing coronavirus information after he made unproven claims about the virus, including one that it is linked to the 5G mobile network.

item.title: Holly Willoughby QUITS Celebrity Juice 12 years after ITV show helped make her a household name
item.description: Holly Willoughby will end her reign as a team captain on the award-winning panel show at the end of the current series. Insiders say the decision comes as a blow to programming chiefs.

item.title: Spaniards mob the streets as they're allowed out for the first time since March 15
item.description: Spaniards flocked to the streets today after being allowed out for the first time since the country introduced harsh lockdown measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus on 15 March.

item.title: Heart-rending plea from the owner of London's oldest family restaurant, JAMES CHIAVARINI
item.description: James Chiavarini, owner of Il Portico restaurant, pictured in front of his restaurant on Kensington Highstreet which was forced to close for the first time in 53 years when London locked down.

item.title: What we can all learn from the 100-year-old super survivors who caught coronavirus - and lived
item.description: Evidence suggests the biggest risk factor for death by Covid-19 is age, but scores of pensioners are bucking the trend by managing to shake off the killer infection.

item.title: Normal People star Paul Mescal lied to BBC producers about being able to drive when he got the role
item.description: He is the breakout star of the BBC's new teenage sex drama Normal People - but actor Paul Mescal has admitted he only got the part after fibbing to BBC producers about whether he could drive.

item.title: Kate Mansey thought her daughter was dead only for her to recover but develop temperature and cough
item.description: They were 30 seconds of my life that must have aged me about ten years. My toddler had tried to climb the stairs and as she tumbled down the last couple of steps on her bottom.

item.title: DIARY OF AN NHS DOCTOR: At 11am, there's a minute's silence for the NHS staff we've lost.
item.description: Since the crisis began, I've been drinking too much coffee to try to stay alert. I've suffered heart palpitations as a result, so I'm going to try detox this week - or at least that's what I'm telling myself.

item.title: Police chief warns officers to stop prancing around in TikTok videos during coronavirus pandemic
item.description: Officers throughout the country are posting videos of themselves dancing online on social media app TikTok, drawing the ire of Chief Constable Gavin Stephens, lead for digital engagement.

item.title: Wuhan virus lab 'cover up'
item.description: During the past month, Wuhan's Institute of Virology has removed photographs of scientists working in its laboratories and edited out references to visits by US diplomats.

item.title: Johnson and Carrie Symonds do not intend to make their newborn baby Wilfred a 'public figure'
item.description: The Mail on Sunday has learnt that Carrie Symonds chose a picture that deliberately did not show the baby's face and will shun the path taken by past PMs who had babies while in Downing Street.

item.title: Culture Minister Oliver Dowden blasts BBC director-general over bias in wake of Panorama programme
item.description: Mr Dowden urged director-general Tony Hall to 'uphold the highest standards in relation to integrity and impartiality' in the wake of the Panorama programme which featured five left-wing activists.

item.title: Actress MARCIA DO VALES reveals what life was like during Madrid's coronavirus lockdown
item.description: After seven weeks of lockdown - forbidden from leaving our homes except for food and medicine - the feeling of the sun on my face felt wonderful, actress MARCIA DO VALES writes.

item.title: We'll never know the true COVID-19 care home death toll, says Care England's Professor Martin Green
item.description: The true scale of the coronavirus crisis 'burning through' care homes may never be known, according head of Care England Professor Martin Green.

item.title: Britons will be allowed to exercise several times each day in the first stage of relaxing lockdown
item.description: Ministers are preparing to lift restrictions on outdoor activities such as picnics as the first stage in relaxing the lockdown. People must be with household members and stay 6ft 6in from others.

item.title: Elderly woman waves a flag from a balcony in Paris to show her support for medical staff
item.description: Stunning images from Saint Mande, a commune of Paris, were taken during the claps for carers that happens every night at 8pm in the country.

item.title: Victoria star Jenna Coleman rules the road on £750 bicycle birthday gift from boyfriend Tom Hughes
item.description: Victoria star Jenna Coleman swapped her throne for a saddle as she took her £750 new bike for a test ride last week. It was a present for her 34th birthday on Monday from boyfriend Tom Hughes.

item.title: Doctors prepared to announce my DEATH, Boris Johnson reveals
item.description: The Prime Minister, 55, has said he was 'not in particularly brilliant shape' while battling the disease at St Thomas' Hospital in central London last month.

item.title: Women who buy designer items are more likely to act in a selfish manner, study finds
item.description: Academics at the University of Maryland carried out experiments to determine how designer goods alter psychology and behaviour.

item.title: Brussels trade talks will collapse within weeks unless EU nations 'get real' about Britain's stance
item.description: Britain is urging Brussels to adopt a more realistic approach to the negotiations to not 'waste time' and include more one-on-one talks with the UK's lead negotiator David Frost (left).

item.title: The last Victoria Cross hero before VE Day who was so brave even the enemy marvelled
item.description: By late April 1945, the German army was in retreat and, after nearly six long years of war, the Allies were finally poised to defeat Adolf Hitler.

item.title: Sex And The City writer Candace Bushnell says she did not have sex for five years after divorce
item.description: As the woman whose newspaper columns spawned the wildly successful Sex And The City franchise, there is little about relationships and sex that Candace Bushnell hasn't encountered.

item.title: Landmark legal bid to force clinics to tell women the truth about what is involved in an abortion
item.description: Ana-Maria Tudor, 32, is launching a legal bid to force clinics to tell their patients that a foetus may feel pain during termination. Ms Tudor claims the current abortion guidelines are out of date.

item.title: Kate Middleton makes 'virtual visit' to an astonished new mother in an NHS maternity unit
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge (pictured) congratulated Rebecca Attwood and took great interest in how the birth had gone during a morale-boosting 'virtual' chat.

item.title: Historic moments of VE Day jubilation stamps
item.description: Seventy-five years ago, a sea of people gathered in Trafalgar Square under a banner on Nelson's Column which declared 'Victory Over Germany 1945'.

item.title: Mothers and daughters: DAME VERA LYNN 'Music reminds us that we're not alone'
item.description: The Forces' Sweetheart DAME VERA LYNN, who's back in the charts aged 103 with her song 'We'll Meet Again', reveals what her wartime hit really means to her and daughter Virginia

item.title: The life-saving violin of Auschwitz - the cherished instrument was Rosa's only chance of survival
item.description: As a young girl, Natalie Cumming listened to her aunt's harrowing accounts of surviving unimaginable horrors in brutal Nazi death camps

item.title: DAN HODGES: If our New Normal is the state telling me who I can and can't see, count me out
item.description: Last week it emerged Ministers are giving serious consideration to the creation of a 'bubble' of ten family members and acquaintances we will be allowed to see as we ease out of lockdown.

item.title: Son, 55, nurses Covid-stricken father, 81, back to health after he was released from hospital to die
item.description: Raj Nathwani (left, with his mother Kanchan, father Suri and brother Manish) also used a Google spreadsheet to monitor 81-year-old Suri's vital signs and kept his house clean in Watford.

item.title: Britons having more food, sex and sleep in lockdown and are less likely to split from partners
item.description: When Boris Johnson announced the stringent stay-at-home measures in March, many predicted: 'The divorce rate is going to go up!'

item.title: Boy, 11, feared to have 'life-changing injuries' after being shot by burglars posing as deliverymen
item.description: The gang forced their way into the family's semi-detached house in Upminster, East London. His father Ray Hawkins, 45, opened the door believing it was a parcel delivery on Friday.

item.title: Space X passes final parachute test ahead its historic launch on May 27
item.description: Space X's final parachute test passed with flying colors ahead of its launch in May It will be the US's first manned in nearly nine years.

item.title: 'Wonder-drug' made to fight ebola could be the world's first real weapon against Covid-19
item.description: US researchers have published early data which suggests a drug, called remdesivir, pictured, could effectively treat people with coronavirus.

item.title: Damage reported as 5.5 quake strikes Puerto Rico
item.description: A 5.4-magnitude earthquake struck near southern Puerto Rico on Saturday, briefly knocking out power and forcing the relocation of at least 50 families.

item.title: Recovered coronavirus patients ARE showing signs of immunity, experts say
item.description: England's deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries (pictured) said a 'very large percentage of patients' had a 'pretty good response' after it was revealed that 621 deaths were recorded today.

item.title: VE Day will be celebrated with message from the Queen and toast given by Joan Collins
item.description: The high point will be the Queen's recorded message on BBC1 at 9pm, the same time as her father, George VI, gave a radio address from Buckingham Palace three-quarters of a century ago.

item.title: Former Supreme Court judge LORD SUMPTION gives a withering critique of the Government's lockdown
item.description: LORD SUMPTION: COVID-19 is not the greatest crisis in our history. But the lockdown is without doubt the greatest interference with personal liberty in British history.

item.title: PETER HITCHENS: We're destroying the nation's wealth - and the health of millions
item.description: PETER HITCHENS: Why do I bother? For six weeks I have been saying the Government's policy on Covid-19 is a mistake. Most people do not agree, and many are angry with me for saying so.

item.title: ALEXANDRA SHULMAN: Lockdown is extra tough with a baby - just ask Boris Johnson
item.description: ALEXANDRA SHULMAN'S NOTEBOOK: I'm not sure what was happening nine months ago but people seem to be popping out babies. Even the Prime Minister and his fiancee.

item.title: Pretty Little Thing founder Umar Kamani worth £1billion took taxpayers' cash to furlough 86 staff
item.description: While the Pretty Little Thing founder enjoys a spa in Dubai, ordinary taxpayers are covering the cost of his employees' wages.

item.title: Farmers urge people across Europe to eat steak, chips and cheese to help clear excess produce
item.description: European farmers are urging people to eat more steak, chips and eggs (stock image) as they are desperate to sell goods that were previously going to the hospitality industry.

item.title: How an Indian guru taught me the life-changing power of giving, says philanthropist Marc Benioff
item.description: Mr Benioff is worth £5.5 billion thanks to the success of the company he founded shortly after that encounter, Salesforce, which employs more than 1,500 in the UK.

item.title: Royal fans go wild over 'uncanny' resemblance between Princess Charlotte and Lady Sarah Chatto
item.description: Royal fans are going wild online over the 'uncanny' resemblance between Princess Charlotte, 5, in her new birthday portraits and the Queen's niece Lady Sarah Chatto's, 55.

item.title: Don't go to the pub with friends after lockdown measures are eased, top medic warns Britons
item.description: England's deputy chief medical officer Dr Jenny Harries said mixing with friends and others outside your household in a small environment like a pub would not be a good idea.

item.title: Channel 4 could cancel this year's Great British Bake Off due to lockdown rules
item.description: Channel 4's Great British Bake off is at risk of being cancelled this year over fears that the coronavirus and lockdown rules could prevent contestants from getting to the tent (pictured).

item.title: Interactive map shows location of hundreds of UK locations that have managed to avoid a fatality
item.description: An interactive map using data from the Office of National Statistics (ONS) has revealed hundreds of towns and villages which have avoided a single Covid-19 fatality during the pandemic.

item.title: At least 171 frontline NHS workers have now died in the coronavirus pandemic including 27 doctors
item.description: At least 171 frontline NHS workers have died in the coronavirus pandemic, latest figures reveal. They include at least 27 doctors and around 100 nurse and healthcare supporters, say Nursing Notes.

item.title: Prince William calls Boris Johnson after the Prime Minister welcomed son Wilfred
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge, 37, called Prime Minister Boris Johnson, 55, for a phone meeting on Friday afternoon, days after the politician welcomed his son Wilfred with fiancee Carrie Symonds, 32.

item.title: Tiny Oxford firm is 'extremely optimistic' over pill it has developed to combat coronavirus
item.description: BerGenBio, a British-Norwegian company with just 38 staff, believe they have found the key to combating the coronavirus. Bemcentinib (pictured) has been fast-tracked to be tried on NHS hospitals.

item.title: Iran and Russia launch hacking attacks on British unis in attempt to steal vaccine secrets
item.description: Hackers from Russia and Iran have been attempting to gain access to British universities that are developing vaccines for the coronavirus. Pictured: Stock image of a hacker.

item.title: DR ELLIE CANNON: The £20 gadget no family should be without during the coronavirus pandemic
item.description: DR ELLIE CANNON reveals how the oximeter, pictured, a simple tool available easily on the high street, can help catch Covid-19 before it turns deadly.

item.title: EVE SIMMONS: What's so wrong with a doctor on the Covid front line enjoying a doughnut on his break?
item.description: EVE SIMMONS: Becoming infected with coronavirus undoubtedly tops the list of current health fears for most Britons. But getting fat seems to come a close second.

item.title: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: I have loathed them for years. Now I discover video games boost the brain!
item.description: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: Like many, I've long believed that our relentless use of social media is, for want of a better term, rotting our brains.

item.title: DOUGLAS MURRAY: Let's hear less from all those spouting daft made-up grievances after the pandemic
item.description: DOUGLAS MURRAY: I hope the crisis will finally call time on so many of the daft, right-on obsessions that have recently wasted so much of our attention, like Extinction Rebellion (pictured, in Germany).

item.title: Son of 83-year-old Robin Hanbury-Tenison on how his father was one of the first coronavirus victims
item.description: MERLIN HANBURY-TENISON: There comes a point in every child's life when they realise their parents aren't invincible. That moment, for me, came later than for most: just six weeks ago.

item.title: Heroic staff get PPE just in time thanks to Mail Force charity
item.description: There was delight among staff at Shedfield Lodge care home in Hampshire following a Mail Force delivery last week. As Shedfield boss, Andrew Geach, put it: 'You are a guardian angel.'

item.title: Woman stranded in remote village in India during the coronavirus lockdown made amazing journey home
item.description: Corinne Henderson, 30, was nearing the end of a three-week trip to visit her friend's family in a remote Indian village when the country went into lockdown. What followed was a journey of a lifetime.

item.title: Colonel Tom Moore's millions is already bringing joy to patients
item.description: People unable to receive hospital visitors have been given the devices after the 100-year-old war veteran raised £32million for NHS charities by walking 100 laps of his garden.

item.title: Doctors plea to give high-risk ethnic minority health workers PPE at all times
item.description: The British International Doctors Association (BIDA) is calling for staff to wear protective equipment, pictured, even when treating non-coronavirus patients

item.title: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway suffers nearly $50billion loss in first quarter
item.description: Berkshire Hathaway, the massive conglomerate run by billionaire Warren Buffett suffered a first-quarter net loss of $49.75 billion as its companies reel from the fall out of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Wuhan biosafety expert admits widespread security and maintenance concerns
item.description: International pressure was last night building on Beijing following the leak of a bombshell intelligence dossier which accuses China of having lied about the origins of Covid-19.

item.title: Celebrate the 75th anniversary of VE Day with this definitive TV guide... plus how to make bunting
item.description: A definitive guide to how you can enjoy the celebrations on TV including an address from the Queen on Friday. Plus how to make bunting and Winston Churchill's Swiss Roll.

item.title: UK announces hundreds more coronavirus deaths
item.description: Officials also recorded another 4,806 cases, with more than 180,000 Britons having now been infected since the crisis hit the UK in February.

item.title: MAX HASTINGS: VE Day saw wild rejoicing but it was tempered by melancholy over the millions who died
item.description: MAX HASTINGS: There was rejoicing in the streets of London on VE Day, driven by both the knowledge that the great evil of Hitler was no longer and the jubilation following six years of sacrifice.

item.title: Former Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman explores Antwerp - a mecca for the fashionista
item.description: Antwerp is one of the most intriguing cities in northern Europe, particularly if you are interested in fashion and design. Alexandra Schulman headed to the city to check out its creative scene.

item.title: Secret places to visit in Britain after lockdown, from hidden bars to deserted islands
item.description: Some of Britain's best-kept secrets, whether stately homes with hidden rooms or bars with concealed entrances, come with fascinating histories. Here we marvel at their magic...

item.title: How to explore the world from home during lockdown: Check in to Danish Downton-by-Sea
item.description: From travelogues to films and even webcams, The Mail on Sunday's Neil Simpson reveals how you can satisfy your wanderlust during the lockdown.

item.title: The betrayal of Harry Dunn
item.description: HARRY COLE: During a TV documentary about life in the Foreign Office, the head of the Diplomatic Service, Sir Simon McDonald, made it clear that he relished his position of power.

item.title: Twitter reacts to Kim Jong-un's return to public life
item.description: Twitter users reacted humorously to reports that Kim Jong-un had not died with one person using an image of WWE wrestler Mark William Calaway, better known as The Undertaker.

item.title: Britons flock outdoors in their thousands for the return of lockdown sunshine
item.description: Queues of customers began lining up at Homebase stores across the country this morning as the DIY chain reopened all of its nationwide branches.

item.title: Statistician estimates almost double government figure but adjusting for excess deaths
item.description: The number of people in Britain who have died because of Covid-19 so far could be as high as 45,000, former ONS data analyst Jamie Jenkins has today warned.

item.title: Duncan Bannatyne reveals newborn granddaughter received hospital care amid coronavirus fears
item.description: The former Dragon's Den star said in a tweet on Saturday that the little girl was born at University Hospital of North Tees in Stockton-on-Tees in Durham.

item.title: China's 'Bat Woman' Shi Zhengli denies 'trying to defect with confidential files'
item.description: Rumors had begun to spread across social media over the past 48 hours that Shi Zhengli had escaped from China, and brought hundreds of confidential documents to the U.S. embassy in Paris.

item.title: People on lockdown share their most hilarious quarantine fails
item.description: People around the world are adapting to life under lockdown during the coronavirus pandemic but some have had to face hilarious set-backs, from mischievous felines to faulty hair equipment.

item.title: Common blood pressure pills DO NOT make coronavirus worse, three studies find
item.description: Doctors sounded the alarm in March after animal studies suggested the pills could warp the shape of human cells and make infection worse. But US researchers say there is no link.

item.title: A son called Wilfred Lawrie Nicholas
item.description: Carrie Symonds has revealed the name of her and Boris Johnson's newborn son is Wilfred, after Boris's grandfather, as the parents shared the first photograph of the baby boy on Instagram.

item.title: Ministers unveil £76million package for domestic violence victims
item.description: Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick announced the funding as he took the daily Downing Street press briefing tonight.

item.title: HMRC is 'inundated' with claims from employees working from home
item.description: Millions who are now working remotely due to the coronavirus pandemic are entitled to claim tax relief for items they say are 'wholly, exclusively and necessarily' to successfully do their job.

item.title: Police arrest anti-lockdown protesters taking part in a 'group hug' outside Met's headquarters
item.description: An activist has been arrested after 5G conspiracy theorists carried out a 'group hug' near the Met Police's headquarters while holding signs with slogans such as 'my body my choice'.

item.title: Married mother-of-three NHS nurse, 63, dies with coronavirus two years before she was due to retire
item.description: Indian-born Philomina Cherian, 63, died at John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford on Thursday after contracting Covid-19. She was called a 'great human being, a caring mother and wife' by her husband.

item.title: Warm spell finally returns after a week of miserable downpours with temperatures set to soar to 65F
item.description: After a week of rain and thunderstorms the spring sunshine is due to return to Britain as temperatures reach as high as 65F this weekend. The weather will be drier for most with some scattered showers.

item.title: Reverend Richard Coles makes emotional radio tribute to sister-in-law who died from coronavirus
item.description: Reverend Richard Coles today invoked the Queen's 'we will meet again' message as he read out a touching tribute to his sister-in-law Louise Coles after her death from coronavirus.

item.title: Royal Navy warship HMS Kent joins American destroyers for training mission
item.description: HMS Kent joined two US destroyers and a nuclear submarine in the Arctic Circle for the training exercise which is taking place in an area where the sea temperatures is around four Celsius.

item.title: Check her out! Princess Charlotte dons sold-out Zara houndstooth dress with £12 leggings
item.description: Princess Charlotte, who is celebrating her fifth birthday today, wore the pretty Zara dress in the trendy and classic royal print as she delivered food to the vulnerable in Norfolk this week.

item.title: Medical experts say 'needle' marks on Kim Jong-un's arms could hint at heart surgery
item.description: Medical experts have assessed video footage of Kim Jong-un's visit to Sunchon and claim marks (pictured) on his arms show he has had a 'cardiovascular procedure'.

item.title: 'I can't wait to move!': Majority of buyers vow to crack on with moves
item.description: Getting the deal done looks set to become a tag-line for the property market as transactions remain on hold and more people look to move outside of big cities like London and Birmingham.

item.title: New Mexico closes roads in Gallup to curb 'uninhibited spread of COVID-19'
item.description: On Friday New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham declared a state of emergency under the state's Riot Control Act in the city of Gallup following a staggering surge in COVID-19 cases.

item.title: Government testing chief plays down Matt Hancock's target amid row
item.description: John Newton brushed off a row over whether the numbers had been cooked, telling the BBC the big picture was capacity had risen and there would always be disputes when 'politicians set targets'.

item.title: 'Once upon a virus': China mocks the US response to the coronavirus crisis with Lego-like animation
item.description: In the animation posted online by China's official Xinhua news agency, a warrior Lego figure wearing a face mask warns a Statue of Liberty figure of the dangers of the virus.

item.title: The Holiday Guru answers questions on coronavirus travel rights
item.description: This week a reader also asks, in light of the pandemic, if they can claim back a 'non-refundable' deposit on a holiday lodge in Scotland.

item.title: Emma Thompson moves to Scotland house for lockdown days after getting Italian citizenship
item.description: Emma Thompson planned to move to Venice after Brexit because she felt European but moved to her Scotland house to stay in lockdown with her family just four days after getting Italian citizenship.

item.title: Councils in 'catastrophe': Town where HALF of workers face being furloughed pleads for PM's help
item.description: Gatwick Airport employs 3,500 people directly with a further 21,000 staff working at some of the 250 firms based at the campus. A further 12,000 jobs are supported indirectly.

item.title: Is this the future of travel? From blood tests during check-in to plastic booths around plane seats
item.description: The only certainty is that the future of travel is uncertain. We'll all have to get used to a whole new travel landscape once coronavirus restrictions are lifted. So what will it look like?

item.title: You might need a splash of Mauritius magic after we get through the coronavirus crisis
item.description: Mark Twain once quoted a Mauritius local as saying that 'heaven was copied after Mauritius' after he visited in 1896. The Daily Mail's Kate Johnson headed to the island to see if it still rings true.

item.title: Sarah Ferguson dons a flower crown as she reads How About a Night Out? for Storytime with Fergie
item.description: The Duchess of York, 60 donned a floral crown as she read How About a Night Out? by Sam Williams for her YouTube series Storytime with Fergie and Friends.

item.title: 'I said goodbye through a nurse on the phone': Widow, 75, describes final words to husband
item.description: Pat Pearce, 75, asked a nurse to tell her husband Allan she was sorry she couldn't be with him and that she 'loved him very much' as he lay dying at University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

item.title: 'They're deluded': Farmer who took on 50 English workers to pick crops just has 7 left
item.description: Farmers have half as many workers picking the fields because seasonal pickers can't travel. Edward Spanton Farm in Kent (pictured) has just 40 of the 80 workers it would usually have.

item.title: More than 70 per cent of high street law firms face closure
item.description: A survey of 774 small legal firms by the Law Society found that 71 per cent may close their doors within six months as face-to-face meetings are increasingly difficult due to the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Yorkshire mother's heartbreak as she buries husband and daughter who died within days of each other
item.description: Former police officer and charity fundraiser David Whinchup, 79, and his daughter, Joanne Rennison, 52, from Cottingham, East Yorkshire, died just days apart.

item.title: Brits head to the TIP! Centres are heaving as councils try to stagger entry as part of phased return
item.description: There were long queues from as early as 8am this morning at dumps in Greater Manchester and Northumberland after local councils were given the green light to open tips today.

item.title: Adorable moment ecstatic pensioner, 92, meets her great grandchild for the first time
item.description: Joan Cartwright, 92, was delighted after her grandson, Will and his wife, Jen, came round to introduce her to her sixth great-grandchild Holly. She leant out of her flat window in Horsforth, Leeds.

item.title: Silverstone boss Stuart Pringle warns British Grand Prix 'is not a given' even without spectators
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has put Formula One's plans to start the season on hold but they races in Austria in early July before potentially two more at Silverstone are being lined up.

item.title: J.K Rowling donates £1million to charities on the 22nd anniversary of the Battle of Hogwarts
item.description: The Harry Potter author, 54, took to Twitter on Saturday to make the announcement, which she thought was fitting on the 22nd anniversary of the Battle of Hogwarts.

item.title: Elon Musk's tweet caused Tesla's market value to tank by $14 billion
item.description: 'Tesla stock price is too high imo,' Musk tweeted on Friday, before going on to vow to sell off his physical possessions and recite part of the national anthem.

item.title: Bombshell US intelligence claims China lied about coronavirus outbreak
item.description: A leaked 15-page dossier from the 'Five Eyes' intelligence alliance states China's secrecy over the pandemic is an 'assault on international transparency'.

item.title: Stay with Dick and Angel at their Escape to the Chateau home
item.description: Dick and Angel Strawbridge are offering fans of Channel 4's Escape to the Chateau a chance to stay at their home as part of a new competition.

item.title: Germany's daily coronavirus cases fall following five days of rising infections
item.description: Germany 's number of coronavirus cases has dropped following five days of rising infections after the government eased the country's lockdown measures earlier this week.

item.title: Ford drive drags woman along road then tries to run her boyfriend over
item.description: Daniel Walmsley, 29, was arrested after footage went viral of him dragging a woman along a road in Newcastle and trying to run her boyfriend over. He was sentenced to over two years in jail.

item.title: People go wild over mouth-watering Vimto cocktail which is the perfect lockdown sweet treat
item.description: Kayleigh Snyder, from Essex, shared a snap of the Vimto cocktail and ingredients on the Extreme Couponing and Bargains UK group, sending social media users into a frenzy.

item.title: Police arrest two men on suspicion of stabbing NHS worker
item.description: The Metropolitan Police arrested a 19-year-old man in Stratford on Friday afternoon after arresting a 17-year-old boy in Telford, Shropshire, on suspicion of murdering NHS worker David Gomoh.

item.title: The Body Coach Joe Wicks reveals he has come round following surgery
item.description: Joe Wicks has revealed he has woken up after undergoing a second operation on his hand at Kingston Hospital in London on Saturday.

item.title: Unions blast British Airways over its plan to send 12,000 staff 'to the dole'
item.description: Unison attacked British Airways accusing it of sending UK workers 'to the dole' after the airline confirmed it would not be seeking a bailout loan from the UK government.

item.title: Some foods CAN be eaten after Best Before day by up to three years later, says government guidance
item.description: WRAP, which advises the government on waste, says tinned goods such as Heinz Beanz and soup, alongside pasta, jars of jam and meat, can be eaten up to three years after their expiration date.

item.title: The Queen and Prince Charles share their 'very best wishes' for Princess Charlotte's birthday
item.description: The Queen, 93, and Prince Charles, 72, were among the first to send their best wishes to Princess Charlotte on Instagram as she celebrates her fifth birthday at Anmer Hall in Norfolk today.

item.title: Mother fought off paedophile after he swung a knife demanding car keys as he is jailed for six years
item.description: Duncan Johnson, 41, demanded Natalie Grimes' keys at an Asda car park in Liverpool as he tried to rob a vehicle with her daughter, seven, inside. He was jailed for six years after the incident in March.

item.title: Clever emoji quiz challenges users to guess the famous artist
item.description: Scottish Twitter user Gigs in Scotland took to social media to share the infuriating quiz, which challengers users to figure out the names of famous British artists, based on emojis.

item.title: Moscow's real coronavirus infection toll is more than 250,000 says the city's mayor
item.description: Moscow Mayor Segei Sobyanin, pictured visiting a specialist coronavirus hospital yesterday, wrote on his blog today that more than 250,000 people have the coronavirus.

item.title: Thousands of protesters stand off with mounted police as they swarm to Huntington Beach
item.description: Between 2,500 and 3,000 anti-lockdown protesters gathered near Huntington Beach boardwalk in California Friday in response to Gov. Gavin Newsom's closure of Orange County beaches.

item.title: New blood plasma Covid-19 treatment set to be trialled at London hospital
item.description: More than 140 NHS patients will be given the treatment at the London hospital in the coming weeks. It is hoped the antibody-rich plasma can bolster the immune system of critically unwell patients.

item.title: Alcoholics including one who hit rock bottom after almost dying reveal how they cope in lockdown
item.description: Former alcoholics tell FEMAIL what it's like to stay away from booze after hitting rock bottom - and offer words of hope to others who may be facing drink problems while coping with lockdown.

item.title: Kim Jong-Un makes his first public appearance for 20 days at a fertiliser plant
item.description: The despot cut the ribbon (pictured) at the opening of a fertiliser factory in Sunchon, state media reported, and released pictures supposedly showing the event.
item.media:credit: KCNA VIA KNS/AFP via Getty Image

item.title: Hong Kong police use pepper spray to clear May Day protest by more than 100 protesters
item.description: A group of 100 protesters met at the New Town Plaza mall in Hong Kong's New Territories, where they sang the protest anthem Glory to Hong Kong and chanted.

item.title: Mum uses her one-year-old daughter to recreate movie scenes
item.description: Jessica Simpson, 32, from Cornwall, spends hours dressing up her 20-month-old daughter Evie in wigd and costumes to recreate movie and TV scenes, including Hellboy and Kill Bill.

item.title: New mother who suffered five miscarriages reveals joy after giving birth to a healthy baby girl
item.description: Danielle Wilson, 24, from Peterborough, suffered a devastating five miscarriages and battled depression as she tried to fulfill her dream of becoming a mother.

item.title: Hundreds of children under the age of six were referred to the government's counterextremism scheme
item.description: More than 500 children under six were referred to the government-led programme which aims to challenge extremist ideologies and help children at risk of radicalisation.

item.title: Hundreds of Germans gather in Berlin to mark May Day despite ban on mass public gatherings
item.description: Police blocked roads around the square in Berlin's Kreuzberg district, traditionally the centre of left-wing May Day protests that had turned violent in the past, to prevent more people from joining.

item.title: Eton to spend £100m on educating disadvantaged children
item.description: Eton's headmaster, Simon Henderson, wants private schools to be on the right side of history after the coronavirus crisis and work towards closing the gap in education inequality with his £100m project.

item.title: Aviation tycoon seeks judicial review of the Covid-19 lockdown
item.description: Millionaire aviation tycoon Simon Dolan, pictured in 2011, has put the government on notice that he will seek a judicial review of the government's lockdown decision.

item.title: Oklahoma mall reopens for the first time since March with restrictions to prevent spread of COVID-19
item.description: Penn Square Mall in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, reopened for the first time since March with multiple restrictions in place designed to prevent the possible spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Gordon Ramsay 'gets warning for flouting lockdown after being spotted miles from Cornwall bolthole'
item.description: Ramsay, 53, has been seen in Rock, Fowey, Port Isaac and Newquay - some distance from his £4million home in Trebetherick. Pictured: The alleged moment Ramsay ran the red light.

item.title: Forget swanky kitchens, a pantry will make your butter and potatoes taste better
item.description: Thinking about it now, the place I was happiest as a child was in my mother's larder. It was that special room where you could cool your bare feet in summer; always dimly lit by a small window.

item.title: Window washers fly through the air as winds of 47mph hit their platform during sudden Florida storm
item.description: The incident, which was caught on video by people standing on a nearby balcony, took place on Thursday afternoon, at the Ritz-Carlton Residences in Sunny Isles Beach, Florida.

item.title: Easy one-pan bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich hack goes viral
item.description: TikTok users are going wild after a home cook from New Jersey shared a very clever way to make a bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich - all in one pan in just a few minutes.
